questions.question_text:
A vSphere administrator sees the alarm:
vSphere HA virtual machine failed to failover
This occurred for a number of virtual machines on a particular ESXi host in a cluster with vSphere High Availability (HA) enabled. The virtual machines guest operating systems never reported a power event.
What occurred?

discussion.content:
Correct answer is D

https://kb.vmware.com/s/article/2034571

Answer is D. If the host failed (powered down), all the VMs would also be powered down. Then HA would take over and power the VMs on a different Host. This would report a power event on the guest operating systems.
Alternatively, if the Host does not fail but looses network connectivity, all VMs remain powered on and the Host has a lock on the VM's so HA fails on the other Hosts because they fail to power on the VM's.
https://kb.vmware.com/s/article/2034571
D is correct. I passed with 500/500 today
D is correct. Passed 07 dec 20 with 500/500

D for sure. 
https://kb.vmware.com/s/article/2034571
what is correct? D?
Obviously is D. VM did not turn off!
D - correct answer
the correct answer is D

I think is D: no power event in the Guest so no restart happended. If the host in disconnected the VM keep running but the HA tries to restart the VMs, HA options can leave VM on a host that has disconnected management network
Failed to fail over means successfully failed over!?

choices.A: The virtual machines were vMotioned off of the ESXi host.
choices.D: The ESXi host is still running but has disconnected from the network.
choices.B: The ESXi host failed and vSphere HA successfully failed over the virtual machines.
choices.C: The previous virtual machine cloning operations failed to complete.

choices.E: Configure the MTU on the VTEP.
choices.B: Configure the MTU on the virtual switch.
choices.A: Configure the MTU on the VMKernel port.
choices.D: Configure the MTU on the LAG group.
choices.C: Configure the MTU on the physical switch.

questions.question_text: What three steps are necessary to enable Jumbo Frames for use with an iSCSI storage array? (Choose three.)

discussion.content:
Think answers are: A,B,C 

https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/6.7/com.vmware.vsphere.networking.doc/GUID-53F968D9-2F91-41DA-B7B2-48394D997F2A.html

choices.A: A disk group must be composed of more than one cache disk and at least one capacity disk.
choices.D: The cache tier should be sized to no less than 10% of the capacity tier.
choices.B: All-Flash configurations do not require a caching tier.
choices.C: A disk group must be composed of one cache disc and at least one capacity disk.

questions.question_text:
A vSphere Administrator is tasked with implementing a production VMware vSAN cluster and has followed the design and sizing guide to correctly size the environment.
Which two requirements represent valid VMware recommendations? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
C: https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/6.7/com.vmware.vsphere.vsan-planning.doc/GUID-1D8956A2-3F46-49C8-9231-38F3A9D09A0F.html

D: https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/6.7/com.vmware.vsphere.vsan-planning.doc/GUID-1D6AD25A-459A-43D6-8FF5-52475499D6A2.html
Correct CD
C and D correct?

just passed now 500/500
correct is B & D

the question refer to a OVF with two o more VM, thats mean that the OVF is from a vApp and need DRS enable cluster for this or a host out a cluster in a vCenter, i think the correct answer is B and D, considering that, option A is from directly in the host and the option D, you are inside the vCenter server
B & D are correct
B and D, I got 500/500 today

https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/6.5/com.vmware.vsphere.vm_admin.doc/GUID-2A95EBB8-1779-40FA-B4FB-4D0845750879.html

Prerequisites
Verify that one of those objects is available in your datacenter.

A standalone host that is running ESX 4.0 or greater.
A cluster that is enabled for DRS.

This is seriously tricky! I believe all four are valid choices. B & C may not be a sure shot based on the configurations - Admission Control, Resource Availability and so on. A & D appear to be a guaranteed option. I would go with A & D.

comments.content: On a different thought, I suspect the key words here are Multiple VM's in the OVF. I suspect that means it's a vApp which can only be deployed on DRS enabled clusters or standalone host connected to vCenter. With this enlightenment, I would now go with B & D :)

This link hints that OVF/OVA could have bundled applications in form of multiple VM's or vApp but does not necessarily state that multiple VMs = vApp. https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/6.5/com.vmware.vsphere.vm_admin.doc/GUID-AE61948B-C2EE-436E-BAFB-3C7209088552.html

discussion.content: OVF with more than one VM means vApp. vApp needs a vcenter client and DRS if on cluster. so answer is B , D

AD. If you right-click on a DRS enabled cluster, Deploy OVF Template... is a valid selection. If you right-click on a Host, Deploy OVF Template... is also a valid selection. A VMware vSphere Hypervisor is name recognized as way to virtualize servers, whether from a template or from an ISO file or even a CDROM.

Answer: B + D (Assuming the OVF is a vAPP!)

https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/6.5/com.vmware.vsphere.vm_admin.doc/GUID-2A95EBB8-1779-40FA-B4FB-4D0845750879.html

Prerequisites:
Verify that one of those objects is available in your datacenter.
- A standalone host that is running ESX 4.0 or greater.
- A cluster that is enabled for DRS.

vApp is what it is and therefore it can be added to DRS Cluster, Standalone Host ( in vCenter that means) and resource pool - https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/6.5/com.vmware.vsphere.vm_admin.doc/GUID-2A95EBB8-1779-40FA-B4FB-4D0845750879.html
It is A and D completely.
I would go with B and D, B because DRS chooses automatically the right ESXi based on usage and D because you need vCenter to deploy an OVF

comments.content: Only if DRS is set to Automatic. If Manual is set, it won't vMotion but only make recommendations.

discussion.content:
I strongly believe it is C and D. This is about knowing requirements for importing an OVF template. You can only import an OVF template when you have vCenter. No matter if you are importing that to an standalone ESX host in vCenter (not part of a cluster but connected to vCenter) OR you can import it to a HA cluster on vCenter no matter if even DRS is enabled or not. 
So A is wrong because it means ESX host (no vCenter)
B is valid but it is not a requirement

comments.content: You can import OVF/OVA into a standalone ESXi host without vCenter.

discussion.content: And why not D? I could be AD because my logic told me with DRS enabled you have no idea how many machines include the OVF and maybe you have not resources for all.

questions.question_text: What are two valid methods to deploy an OVF template which consists of two or more VMs? (Choose two.)

choices.A: Deploy on the VMware vSphere Hypervisor.
choices.C: Deploy on a vSphere HA enabled cluster.
choices.B: Deploy on a vSphere DRS enabled cluster.
choices.D: Deploy on the standalone host connected to vCenter Server.

discussion.content:
A and D are correct: 
https://www.nakivo.com/blog/vmware-distributed-switch-configuration/
C and D is correct ans.

comments.content:
A and D
A distributed virtual switch is a logical switch that is created on vCenter Server and is applied to all ESXi hosts added to the distributed virtual switch. Is available only if you use the vSphere Enterprise Plus license for ESXi hosts in vSphere

questions.question_text: What is required to create a vSphere Distributed Switch? (Choose two.)

choices.B: Login to the ESXi Host with the Root account.
choices.A: vSphere Enterprise Plus licensing is required.
choices.C: A minimum of two physical uplinks is required.
choices.D: The host is added to a vCenter Server.
